MIAMI, Aug 17, 2024 (BSS/AFP) - Hurricane Ernesto lashed Bermuda with heavy rains and strong winds early Saturday as it neared the British Atlantic Ocean territory, with meteorologists warning of a dangerous storm surge and floods.

Its slow speed — moving north-northeast at 13 mph — and large size means Bermuda could experience a lengthy pummeling on Saturday night, the hurricane center said.
On Friday it had been classified as a Category 2 storm, with extremely dangerous winds capable of extensive damage.
While it may continue to weaken for the next day or so, it is forecast to strengthen again over the Gulf Stream, the hurricane center said.
Rainfall on Bermuda was forecast at up to 9 inches, the hurricane center said.
Swells generated by Ernesto were already affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

Hurricane Ernesto weakens, but still dangerous, as it closes in on BermudaBy Jasmine Patterson and Nicola MuirheadBERMUDA (Reuters) - Hurricane Ernesto was weakening as it closed in on Bermuda early on Saturday, downgraded to a Category 1 storm but still threatening the British island territory with powerful winds, a dangerous storm surge and potentially deadly flooding.
Its slow speed - moving north-northeast at 13 mph (20 kph) - and large size means Bermuda could experience a lengthy pummeling on Saturday night, the hurricane center said.
While it may continue to weaken for the next day or so, it is forecast to strengthen again over the Gulf Stream, the hurricane center said.
Rainfall on Bermuda was forecast at up to 9 inches (225 mm), the hurricane center said.
Swells generated by Ernesto were already affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

BERMUDA (Reuters) - Hurricane Ernesto was weakening as it closed in on Bermuda early on Saturday, downgraded to a Category 1 storm but still threatening the British island territory with powerful winds, a dangerous storm surge and potentially deadly flooding.
Its slow speed - moving north-northeast at 13 mph (20 kph) - and large size means Bermuda could experience a lengthy pummeling on Saturday night, the hurricane center said.
While it may continue to weaken for the next day or so, it is forecast to strengthen again over the Gulf Stream, the hurricane center said.
Rainfall on Bermuda was forecast at up to 9 inches (225 mm), the hurricane center said.
Swells generated by Ernesto were already affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

Ernesto was carrying top sustained winds of 85 mph (140 kph) the U.S. National Hurricane Center said, although it had weakened to a Category 1 storm on the five-step Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale as it approached.
Ernesto was expected to slowly depart Bermuda during Saturday, moving north-northeast on a track that would take it near or east of Newfoundland on Monday night, the hurricane center said.
The storm was carrying a dangerous storm surge that was expected to produce significant coastal flooding in parts of Bermuda, while rainfall was forecast at up to 9 inches (225 mm), the center said.
Little change in its current strength was expected during Saturday, although some re-intensification was possible late in the weekend before weakening begins on Monday, the hurricane center said.
Ocean swells generated by Ernesto were affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

TEMPO.CO, Bermuda - Hurricane Ernesto landed on Bermuda early on Saturday, August 17, and was expected to batter the British island territory with powerful winds, a dangerous storm surge, and potentially deadly flooding.
Ernesto was carrying top sustained winds of 85 mph (140 kph) the U.S. National Hurricane Center said.
However, it had weakened to a Category 1 storm on the five-step Saffir-Simpson hurricane scale as it approached.
Ernesto was expected to slowly depart Bermuda on Saturday, moving north-northeast on a track that would take it near or east of Newfoundland on Monday night, the hurricane center said.
Ocean swells generated by Ernesto were affecting parts of Bermuda, the Bahamas, and the east coast of the United States, the hurricane center said.

Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year's Atlantic hurricane season.

MEXICO CITY (AP) — Hurricane Ernesto which made landfall on the tiny British Atlantic territory of Bermuda early Saturday was downgraded to a tropical storm by afternoon, according to the National Hurricane Center.
Earlier, the U.S. National Hurricane Center warned of strong winds, a dangerous storm surge and significant coastal flooding.
Due to the large size of the storm and its slow movement, tropical storm force winds and gusts to hurricane force are expected to continue through Saturday afternoon, with tropical storm-strength winds continuing well into Sunday, the Bermuda government said.
The Bermuda Weather Service confirmed the passage of the eye was from 5:30 am to 8:30 am local time in Bermuda.
Ernesto is the fifth named storm and the third hurricane of this year’s Atlantic hurricane season.

Even with the storm hundreds of miles offshore, Hurricane Ernesto was still being felt Saturday along much of the Eastern Seaboard, with dangerous rip currents forcing public beaches to close during one of the final busy weekends of the summer season.
No injuries were reported, the park service reported.
A park service news release said other homes in and near Rodanthe appeared to have sustained damage.
Significant debris removal wasn’t expected until early next week after the elevated sea conditions subside, the park service said.
It also warned this weekend of rip currents and large waves, reaching north into Virginia and Maryland beaches.
